words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek βουλευτής (bouleutḗs, “counsellor”).
words.Ancient_Context: βουλευτήσ 'councillor, senator' (Herodotus Historicus 9.5) | βουλευτήσ 'councillor, senator' (Plato Philosophus Ap. 25a) | βουλευτήσ 'one of the' (Aristophanes Comicus Thucydides Historicus 808)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek σχολή (skholḗ).
words.Modern_Def: faculty, school (division of institutions of higher education)
words.Ancient_Context: μὴ σχολὴν τίθει 'i.e. make haste' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ag. 1059) | σχολῆσ τόδ' ἔργον 'a work for leisure, i.e. requiring attention' (Euripides Tragicus Andr. 552) | σ. ἔχειν 'to have leisure' (Euripides Tragicus Andr. 732)
ἡ εἰσ Ἅιδου, εἰσ Πέρσασ π., (Plato Philosophus Phd. 115a) | πορεία 'running, gait,' (Plato Philosophus Smp. 190b) | πορεία 'journey,' (Aeschylus Tragicus Pr. 823)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek συνέχεια (sunékheia), from συνεχής (sunekhḗs) + -εια (-eia).
words.Modern_Def: continuation, continuity, continuance (the quality of being continuous without interruption)
words.Ancient_Context: κατὰ συνέχειαν ἀριθμεῖσθαι 'to be reckoned by conjunction (e.g' (1) | αἱ κατὰ συνέχειαν προτάσεισ, 'cf' (Stoicorum Veterum Fragmenta 2.71) | σ. γίνεται 'there is a continuous succession (of flowering' (Id. HP 6.8.4)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek ποίημα (poíēma).
words.Ancient_Context: π. ἐραστοῦ 'a lover's invention' (Id. R. 474e) | ποίημα 'work,' (Plato Philosophus Menander Comicus 97e) | ποίημα 'poem,' (Plato Philosophus Phd. 60d)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Koine Greek πολιτισμός (politismós), from Ancient Greek πολίτης (polítēs) + -
Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek δημιουργός (dēmiourgós, “worker for the common good”). Synchron
words.Modern_Def: creator of original works, craftsman, artisan
words.LSJ_Definition: one who works for the people, skilled workman, handicraftsman; ἰδιώτησ,
words.Ancient_Context: δ. κακῶν 'author of ill' (Euripides Tragicus Fr. 1059.7) | ἐχάλκευσε ξίφοσ . . Αιδησ δ. ἄγριοσ (Sophocles Tragicus Aj. 1035) | οἱ δ. 'the artisan class at Athens' (Aristoteles Philosophus Athenaeus Grammaticus 13.2)

words.LSJ_Definition: interchange; conciliation; ἐν ξυναλλαγῇ λόγου; reconciling
words.Ancient_Context: ἐν ξυναλλαγῇ λόγου 'by reconciling words' (Sophocles Tragicus Aj. 732) | λέκτρων ἦλθεσ ἐσ συναλλαγάσ 'of a procuress' (Euripides Tragicus Hipp. 652) | ἔν τε δαιμόνων συναλλαγαῖσ 'in the dealings of men with the immortals' (Sophocles Tragicus OT 34)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek ἀγορά (agorá).
words.Modern_Def: agora, the ancient square or marketplace, the centre of public life
words.Ancient_Context: ἀ. Πυλάτιδεσ 'of the Amphictyonic Council at Pylae' (Sophocles Tragicus Tr. 638) | ἔσχ' ἀγοράων 'withheld him from speaking' (Ilias 2.275) | ὀρθῶν ἑσταότων ἀ γένετ' οὐδέ τισ ἔτλη ἕζεσθαι (Ilias 18.246)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek σύνθεσις (súnthesis); the maintenance of /n/ before /θ/ (except colloqu
words.Modern_Def: composition (the formation of the complex by combination of simpler)
words.Ancient_Context: γραμμάτων τε συνθέσεισ 'i.e. syllables and words' (Aeschylus Tragicus Pr. 460) | σ. ἔκ τε ῥημάτων γιγνομένη καὶ ὀνομάτων 'i.e. sentences' (Plato Philosophus Sph. 263d) | ἐκ συνθέσεωσ 'by arrangement' (Diodorus Siculus Historicus 13.112)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek βουλή (boulḗ).
words.Modern_Def: parliament, legislative body, house of elected representatives
words.Ancient_Context: τούτοισ οὐκ ἔστι κοινὴ β. 'they have no common ground of argument' (Plato Philosophus Cri. 49d) | ἡ β. ἡ ἐν Ἀρείῳ πάγῳ 'ibid.; also ); in other states, as at Argos' (Herodotus Historicus 7.149) | βουλ ὴν ἷζε γερόντων (Ilias 2.53)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek πολίτευμα (políteuma, “business of government”).
words.LSJ_Definition: business of government, act of administration
words.Ancient_Context: ἔν τε τοῖσ κατὰ τὴν πόλιν π. καὶ ἐν τοῖσ Ἑλληνικοῖσ 'both in my home and foreign policy' (Id. 18.109) | οἱ ἐν π. 'the citizens, ib' (1303b26) | Καυνίων τὸ π. 'at Sidon' (OGI 592)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From the accusative of Ancient Greek πατρίς (patrís). Compare Mariupol Greek патридъа (patriða).
words.LSJ_Definition: of one's fathers; πατρὶσ αἶα, ἄρουρα; one's fatherland, country
words.Ancient_Context: πατρὶσ αἶα, ἄρουρα 'one's fatherland, country' (Odyssea 10.236) | π. γάρ ἐστι πᾶσ' ἵν' ἂν πράττῃ τισ εὖ 'ubi bene, ibi patria' (Aristophanes Comicus Plato Philosophus 1151) | π. πόλισ 'the city of one's sires' (Pindarus Lyricus O. 10(11).36)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek συνέδριον (sunédrion).
words.Modern_Def: congress, colloquium, conference (gathering of people for the purpose of discussion)
words.Ancient_Context: τὰ σ 'of the' (600) | ἐν σ 'in court' (Lysias Orator 9.6) | συνέδριον 'congress' (Herodotus Historicus 8.56)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learnedly from παρεμβαίνω (paremvaíno) + -ση (-si), a calque of French intervention.
words.Modern_Def: intervention (the action of intervening; interfering in some course of events)
words.Ancient_Context: τεθρίππῳ π 'to be mounted beside another on' (Dionysius Halicarnassensis 2.34)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Koine Greek παραγωγή (paragōgḗ, “creation”) with semantic loan from French pr
words.Modern_Def: production (the act of producing, making or creating something)
words.Ancient_Context: ἡ π. ἡ διὰ τοῦ "φι" (Apollonius Dyscolus Grammaticus Adv. 194.22) | λόγοσ ταῦτα καὶ π. τοῦ πράγματοσ 'attempt to mislead as to the facts' (Id. 30.26) | π. τῶν κωπῶν 'sliding motion of the oars, so that they made no splash in coming out of the water' (Xenophon Historicus HG 5.1.8)

words.Modern_Def: preparation beforehand (the act of getting ready)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek παροχή (parokhḗ) with semantic loan from English supply.
words.LSJ_Definition: supply, furnishing; νεῶν παροχῇ; with liability to furnish
words.Ancient_Context: αἱ τῶν ξενίων π 'in the case of ambassadors' (Polybius Historicus 21.18.3) | νεῶν παροχῇ 'with liability to furnish ships' (Thucydides Historicus 6.85) | παροχή 'with liability to furnish' (Thucydides Historicus 6.85)

words.Modern_Def: to take care of (a child, an obligation, etc.)
words.Ancient_Context: οἲ τοὺσ φίλουσ βλάπτοντεσ οὐ φροντίζετε 'who though ye do mischief to your friends reck not of it' (Euripides Tragicus Hec. 256) | πεφροντικὸσ βλέπεισ 'you look careworn' (Euripides Tragicus Alcaeus Lyricus 773) | δεινά . . τοῖσ τεκοῦσι φροντίσαι (Aeschylus Tragicus Persius Poeta Latinus 245)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Koine Greek διασκεδάζω (diaskedázō, “to disperse”), from Ancient Greek διασκε
words.Modern_Def: to disperse (usually of suspicions, negative feelings)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learnedly, from Hellenistic Koine Greek διεξάγω (diexágō). Morphologically, δι- from δια- (di- from
words.Modern_Def: to carry out, conduct (of talks, diplomatic talks, games)
words.Ancient_Context: δύναμιν διὰ τειχῶν (Diodorus Siculus Historicus 14.20) | δ. τοὺσ βίουσ ἀπό τινοσ 'support life' (Id. 1.71.1) | τροφὴ διεξάγουσα 'laxative diet' (Aretaeus Medicus CA 2.5)
ἀ. χρόνοσ 'time occupied in rising' (Geminus Astronomicus 7.18) | ἀ. σελήνη 'waxing moon, Xenccr. ap' (Oribasius Medicus 2.58.77) | ἀνατολικοί,  '= Orientales, title of a numerus' (PFlor. 278)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek λοιπός (loipós).
words.Ancient_Context: ὃ δὲ λ. 'quod superest' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ag. 1571) | ὁ λ. χρόνοσ 'the future' (Pindarus Lyricus N. 7.67) | τὸν λ. χρόνον 'for the future' (Sophocles Tragicus Philo Judaeus 84)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek ὀρθόδοξος (orthódoxos), equivalent to ορθό- (orthó-, “correct, ortho-”) + δόξα (d
words.Modern_Def: Orthodox (follower of any of the Eastern Orthodox churches)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek παιδαγωγικός (paidagōgikós).
words.Ancient_Context: ἡ -κὴ τῶν νοσημάτων ἰατρική 'system of medicine which waits upon diseases' (Plato Philosophus R. 406a) | παιδαγωγικόσ 'waits upon' (Plato Philosophus R. 406a) | λόγοσ 'title of a treatise on education by Cleomenes the Cynic' (Diogenes Laertius 6.75)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek κορυφαῖος (koruphaîos). By surface analysis, κορυφή (koryfí) +
words.Modern_Def: corypheus (the conductor or leader of the dramatic chorus in Ancient Greece)
words.Ancient_Context: κ. ἑστηκώσ 'standing at the head of the row' (Aristophanes Comicus Plato Philosophus 953) | ὁ κ. πῖλοσ 'the apex of the Roman flamen' (Plutarchus Biographus et Philosophus Marc. 5) | τὰ κ. τῆσ νίκησ 'the crowning fruits of' (Herodianus Rhetor 8.3.5)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From the Ancient Greek Ἑλληνῐκός (Hellēnĭkós).
words.Modern_Def: Greek, Hellenic (related to the country, people or language of Greece)
words.Ancient_Context: οὐχ Ἑ. λέξισ 'Orusap' (Eustathius Episcopus Thessalonicensis 859.55) | τὸ Ἑ 'the Greeks collectively' (Herodotus Historicus 7.139) | τὰ Ἑ 'the history of Greek affairs' (Thucydides Historicus 1.97)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Back-formation from προοπτική (prooptikí, “perspective”, noun) with -ικός (-ikós) suffix.
words.Modern_Def: perspective (of, in or relating to perspective)
words.Ancient_Context: Προοπτικόν,  'title of work by Heraclides' (Diogenes Laertius 5.88)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek πολύς (polús, “many”).
words.Ancient_Context: Κύπρισ γὰρ οὐ φορητόσ, ἢν πολλὴ ῥυῇ 'if she flow with full stream, metaph. from a river' (Euripides Tragicus Hipp. 443) | Ἑλένα μία τὰσ πολλάσ, τὰσ πάνυ π. ψυχὰσ ὀλέσασ' 'those many lives' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ag. 1456) | καί, πολέεσ τε καὶ ἐσθλοί 'many men and good' (Ilias 6.452)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek μόνιμος (mónimos); equivalent to μένω (méno) + -ιμος (-imos).
words.Ancient_Context: ὁ μέγασ ὄλβοσ οὐ μ. (Euripides Tragicus Or. 340) | ἄστρα μ. 'fixed stars' (Pollux Grammaticus 4.156) | οἶνοσ μ. 'wine which will keep' (PGrenf. 2.24.14)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learnedly, from Koine Greek προφανῶς (prophanôs), adverb of the Ancient Greek προφανής (prophanḗs, a
words.Ancient_Context: ἐκ τοῦ προφανεστάτου (Diodorus Siculus Historicus 12.39) | ἀπὸ τοῦ προφανοῦσ 'openly' (Thucydides Historicus 1.35) | στομάτων προφανέων 'f.l. in' (Hippocrates Medicus Mul. 1.17)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek λόγῳ (lógōi), dative singular of λόγος (lógos, “reason, logic”), a calque of Fren
words.Modern_Def: because of, due to, owing to, on account of (as a consequence of)
words.Ancient_Context: μὴ φῦναι τὸν ἅπαντα νικᾷ λ. 'excels the whole account, i.e. is best of all' (Sophocles Tragicus OC 1225) | Τροίαν . . ἧσ ἁπανταχοῦ λ. 'whose fame, story fills the world' (Euripides Tragicus IT 517) | οὐκ ἔχει λόγον 'it is not arguable, i.e. reasonable' (Sophocles Tragicus El. 466)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek ἀσφαλῶς (asphalôs, “steadfastly”).
words.LSJ_Definition: not liable to fall, immovable, steadfast
words.Ancient_Context: φρονεῖν γὰρ οἱ ταχεῖσ οὐκ ἀσφαλεῖσ 'the hasty in counsel are not safe' (Sophocles Tragicus OT 617) | ἀσφαλέωσ, ἔχειν, μένειν, 'to be, remain firm, steady' (Ilias 23.325) | θεῶν ἕδοσ ἀ. αἰεί (Odyssea 6.42)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Byzantine Greek γύρω (gúrō), from γύρος (gúros) (accusative γύρωθεν (gúrōthen)).
words.Modern_Def: around, close by (in the locality of)
words.LSJ_Definition: rounded, curved, crooked; γυρὸσ ἐν ὤμοισι; round- | ring, circle
words.Ancient_Context: γυρὸσ ἐν ὤμοισι 'round- shouldered' (Odyssea 19.246) | γ. πάλη, 'i.e. wrestling' (Philostratus Sophista Gym. 11) | κόνισ, 'of a tomb, ib' (7.180)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Byzantine Greek εἶμαι (eîmai), from Ancient Greek εἰμί (eimí, “to be”), from Proto-Hellenic *eh
From Ancient Greek ἔχω (ékhō, “to have”). Cognate with Mariupol Greek э́ху (éxu).
words.Modern_Def: to have/hold, in the sense of holding (in one's possession) (a [legal/personal/possibly 'undesired']) property
words.Ancient_Context: ἔ. χερσίν, ἐν χερσίν, μετὰ χερσίν 'etc' (Ilias 13.200) | ἔχε . . ἀρὰν ἐπ' ἄλλοισ 'point it against others' (Sophocles Tragicus Philo Judaeus 1119) | ἕξω δ' ὡσ ὅτε τισ στερεὴ λίθοσ 'I will keep unmoved, as a stone' (Odyssea 19.494)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Byzantine Greek ἐμπορῶ (emporô), ἠμπορῶ (ēmporô), ultimately from Ancient Greek εὐπορ
words.LSJ_Definition: one who goes on ship-board as a passenger
words.Ancient_Context: ἔ. βίου 'a trafficker in life' (Euripides Tragicus Hipp. 964) | ἔ. κακῶν (Aeschylus Tragicus Persius Poeta Latinus 598) | ὥρησ ἔ. 'a dealer in beauty' (AP 9.416)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek κάμνω (kámnō).
words.Ancient_Context: οὔτοι καμοῦμαι . . λέγουσα 'I shall never be tired of saying' (Aeschylus Tragicus Eu. 881) | οὐ καμῇ τοὐμὸν μέροσ 'wilt not have to complain' (Sophocles Tragicus Tr. 1215) | οὐκ ἴσον καμὼν ἐμοὶ λύπησ 'not having borne an equal share of grief' (Sophocles Tragicus El. 532)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Hellenistic Koine Greek γίνομαι (gínomai), from Ancient Greek γίγνομαι (gígnomai).
words.Ancient_Context: γιγνομέναισι λάχη τάδ' . . ἐκράνθη 'at our birth' (Aeschylus Tragicus Eu. 347) | ; οὐκ ἂν ἐμοί γε ἐλπομένῳ τὰ γένοιτο 'i.e. I could not hope to see these things take place' (Odyssea 3.228) | ὑπὸ Τμώλῳ γεγαῶτασ 'born (and so living ) under Tmolus' (Ilias 2.866)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek ὑπάρχω (hupárkhō, “to begin, to exist”).
words.LSJ_Definition: take the initiative in, begin; ἀδίκων ἔργων, ἀδικίησ,
words.Ancient_Context: οἶκοσ δ' ὑ. τῶνδε . . ἔχειν 'there is store of these things for us to have' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ag. 961) | τὰ ὑπάρχοντα, 'much' (Aeschylus Tragicus 4) | ἄξιον τῶν ὑ. 'equivalent to what was done for him' (Aristoteles Philosophus EN 1163b21)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from third-person singular πρέπει (prépei) of Ancient Greek πρέπω (prépō).
words.Modern_Def: to be fit for, to be worthy of, deserve
words.LSJ_Definition: to be clearly seen, to be conspicuous
words.Ancient_Context: τοῦδε γὰρ δράμημα φωτὸσ Περσικὸν πρέπει μαθεῖν 'his running is like Persian to behold' (Aeschylus Tragicus Persius Poeta Latinus 247) | πρέπων ἔφυσ πρὸ τῶνδε φωνεῖν 'art the fit person to' (Sophocles Tragicus OT 9) | π. τινὶ εἶδοσ 'to be like one in form' (Pindarus Lyricus P. 2.38)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek βλέπω (blépō), from Proto-Hellenic *gʷlépō. The perfective forms (stem δ-/ειδ-) a
words.Ancient_Context: βλέποντα νῦν μὲν ὄρθ' ἔπειτα δὲ σκότον 'i. e. being blind' (Sophocles Tragicus OT 419) | μὴ βλέπων ὁ μάντισ ᾖ 'lest he see too clearly' (Sophocles Tragicus OT 747) | ἐξ αὑτοῦ βλεπόμενον 'self- evident' (Sextus Empiricus Philosophus M. 1.184)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek θέλω (thélō), a parallel form of ἐθέλω (ethélō).
words.Ancient_Context: τί δὴ θέλων 'with what intent ?' (Aeschylus Tragicus Pr. 118) | μίμνειν οὐκ ἐθέλεσκον ἐναντίον 'they cared not to make a stand, i.e. they were un able' (Ilias 13.106) | μὴ ἔθελε 'c. inf., do not' (Ilias 1.277)

words.Etymology_Snippet:
Inherited from Byzantine Greek βρίσκω (brískō), from Ancient Greek εὑρίσκω (heurískō).
The simple pa
words.Ancient_Context: τὰ δ' ἔργα τοὺσ λόγουσ εὑρίσκεται 'deeds make themselves words' (Sophocles Tragicus El. 625) | εὑ. μητρὶ φόνον 'bring about murder' (Euripides Tragicus El. 650) | ὄνομ' εὕρεο 'think of a name to give him' (Odyssea 19.403)

knots.Nuance: Verbs are oxytone (ending stressed). Characterized by the 'ει' or 'ου' vowels in Active Present endings. No alternative 1st Sg -άω exists.
Endings are identical to the Passive Dependent of all conjugations. Stress always falls on the first (or only) syllable of the ending.
Monosyllabic dependent forms (Active Perfective Stem only, e.g., βγω) are oxytone (ending stressed). Endings match Type 2B Active Present forms.
Verbs are oxytone (ending stressed). Characterized by the 'α' vowel in Active Present endings. Often have alternative 1st Sg -άω (uncontracted).

knots.Description: Nouns in -α (Parisyllabic, Gen. Pl. Penult Stress)
knots.Nuance: Proparoxytone nouns (e.g., those in -ότητα, -ύτητα) shift stress to the penultimate in Gen Pl. Learned Gen Sg in -ος or Nom Sg in -ς/-ξ sometimes used in formal contexts [13, 14].

knots.Description: Nouns in -α (Parisyllabic, Gen. Pl. Final Stress)
knots.Nuance: Stress obligatorily falls on the final syllable in Gen Pl (e.g., θαλασσών), regardless of Nom Sg stress position. Learned Gen Sg in -ης sometimes used in formal discourse [15, 16].
Verbs that do not take a direct object.
Intransitive impersonal verbs (πρέπει) require a complement να-clause.
